ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Postconcussive Tinnitus and Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Onset of bilateral multitoned tinnitus and sound sensitivity immediately followed a motor vehicle accident and moderate concussion.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Exploding Head Syndrome
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports hearing abrupt loud sounds (bangs/explosions) when falling asleep, followed by fear and confusion.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: High-Frequency Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometry reveals mild-to-moderate hearing loss from 6 to 12.5 kHz bilaterally.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Central Auditory Processing Deficits
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Difficulty hearing in noise despite normal speech recognition in quiet; a known sequela of concussions.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity across standard and high frequencies.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To assess the acoustic reflex arc, though often deferred in hyperacusis.
To identify the frequency characteristics of the patient's tinnitus.
To estimate the perceived loudness of the tinnitus.
To determine the level of noise required to cover the tinnitus.
To quantify sound tolerance and dynamic range.
To check for temporary suppression of tinnitus after noise exposure.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation revealed normal hearing in the standard range with high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Significant hyperacusis was evidenced by reduced Loudness Discomfort Levels (75-80 dB HL). Tinnitus assessment showed a multitonal percept (high-frequency noise and 1 kHz tone) with partial residual inhibition. Middle ear function was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal limits 250-4000 Hz; mild-to-moderate SNHL from 6 to 12.5 kHz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs 10 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 100% at 40 dB SL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type A bilaterally (normal volume, admittance, and pressure).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Could not be tested due to patient's report of sound sensitivity.

tests.name: Tinnitus Pitch Match
tests.result_summary: Primary: 6 kHz FRESH noise (central). Secondary: 1 kHz pure tone (louder in right).

tests.name: Tinnitus Loudness Match
tests.result_summary: FRESH noise matched at 5-7 dB SL; 1 kHz tone matched at 10 dB SL.

tests.name: Minimum Masking Level
tests.result_summary: 21 dB SL (ref: broadband threshold of -5 dB HL).

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels
tests.result_summary: Reduced dynamic range; LDLs 75-80 dB HL across frequencies.

tests.name: Residual Inhibition
tests.result_summary: Partial suppression (loudness reduced from 8/10 to 5/10) after 1-2 minutes of white noise.

proposed_items: Binaural Widex Evoke 440 Fusion 2 receiver-in-the-canal (RIC) hearing aids coupled to open domes.
Low-gain amplification (5 dB) provided across all frequencies.
Implementation of Zen fractal tones programs (with and without amplification/noise) for tinnitus management.
White noise program for desensitization of hyperacusis.
Sound therapy focused on habituation and desensitization.
counseling_actions: Explain the connection between concussion, the auditory system, and the autonomic nervous system.
Discuss Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT) principles, focusing on habituation and neutralizing emotional reaction.
Advise against using earplugs in daily environments to avoid preventing desensitization.
Counsel on the nature of Exploding Head Syndrome to reduce fear.

escalation.rationale_short: Patient has been medically cleared; proceed with audiological management of tinnitus and hyperacusis.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor tinnitus distress (THI), hyperacusis impact (HQ), and LDLs; adjust hearing aid settings.

expected_outcome: Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI) score reduced from 48 (moderate) at baseline to 16 at the 3-month follow-up.
Hyperacusis Questionnaire score reduced from 72 (severe) at baseline to 36 at the 3-month follow-up.
Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs) improved by 3 to 5 dB across all frequencies (range 78-83 dB HL) at the 5-month follow-up.
Pure-tone thresholds remained unchanged on repeat audiogram.
Patient reported an overall decrease in sound sensitivity and improvement in tinnitus distress, though still required some decompression time.
